SUMMARY: Allose utilization regulator, AlsR, negatively controls expression of genes involved in transport and catabolism of D-allose and low-affinity transport of D-ribose [8576032, 9401019]. It is negatively autoregulated and coordinately represses transcription of divergent gene rpiB, encoding an enzyme in pentose pathway [8576032]. Synsis of alsR and rpiB genes is induced when Escherichia coli is grown on d-allose in absence of glucose. Gene induction occurs when physiological inducer, d-allose, binds to AlsR, liberating repression effect caused by this protein [9401019, 10559180]. As a member of RpiR/YebK/YfhH family of transcriptional regulators, AlsR features an N-terminal domain containing a helix-turn-helix motif [8576032]. Currently, no DNA-binding sites for this regulator have been reported in literature.
